word.entryDescription: a bird that swims on water; has a wide round beak
word.entryExample: We have lots of ducks on our farm.

word.entryDescription: a young duck
word.entryExample: Can you see the ducks and their ducklings?
I thought their act was dull.

word.entryDescription: a hill made of sand, near the sea or in a desert
word.entryExample: No more than 30% of the Arabian Desert has sand dunes.

word.entryDescription: (plural 'duties') a task you have to do as a part of your job
word.entryExample: Duties include checking that students are in classes and organising afternoon and evening sports and social activities.

word.entryDescription: like a CD but able to store much more data, often used to store films
word.entryExample: A film on DVD is always a good present for somebody you like.

word.entryDescription: a machine used for playing video DVDs
word.entryExample: This DVD player doesn't work any more, we need to buy a new one.

word.entryDescription: the style the interior of a building is decorated in
word.entryExample: The artistic décor was a strong point too, with paintings by local artists.

word.entryDescription: a book that is not printed on paper and which you read on a computer screen or on a device that you hold in your hands
word.entryExample: You can fit an e-book in your pocket and so take reading everywhere with you.

word.entryDescription: one another; used to show that each person in a group does something to or for other people in the group
word.entryExample: I'm sad because I feel a little jealous because Emma and Harry hung out with each other.

word.entryDescription: a part of the body on your head that you use for hearing
word.entryExample: This hat covers my ears!

word.entryDescription: a pain in your ear
word.entryExample: I've got an earache, doctor.

word.entryDescription: sooner than normal
word.entryExample: Emma woke up early.

word.entryDescription: to make money by working
word.entryExample: If she gets a good job, she'll earn lots of money.

word.entryDescription: a small accessory worn in the ear
word.entryExample: She has stolen (well, she says 'borrowed') my favourite earrings.

word.entryDescription: an event in which the ground shakes suddenly
word.entryExample: In an earthquake, it's extremely important to stay calm.

word.entryDescription: the direction from which the sun comes up into the sky in the morning
word.entryExample: The sun rises in the east.

word.entryDescription: something that is easy does not need a lot of work or effort to do
word.entryExample: The questions in the test are easy.

word.entryDescription: to take food into your body through your mouth
word.entryExample: What do you usually eat for breakfast?

word.entryDescription: to have a meal in a restaurant
word.entryExample: Shall we eat out tonight?

word.entryDescription: a medical condition in which you are ill because of not eating a normal amount of food
word.entryExample: There have never been so many eating disorders.

word.entryDescription: a handheld device that displays books in electronic form
word.entryExample: Oh no, I must have left my ebook-reader on a bus!

word.entryDescription: choosing from or using a variety of styles, ideas
word.entryExample: She has an eclectic taste in music as she likes everything from classical music to modern techno.

word.entryDescription: the study of matters relating to the economy
word.entryExample: I have studied home economics, business management and maths at school.

word.entryDescription: all the living things in a particular area and the relationships and processes that operate between them and their environment
word.entryExample: The rainforest ecosystem is vital to the survival of the world so we must all protect it.

word.entryDescription: the process of teaching and learning
word.entryExample: In the past, nurses were usually poor and didn't have much education.

word.entryDescription: a round thing with a hard shell and liquid inside that we get from a chicken and that we can cook and eat
word.entryExample: Can I have eggs for breakfast, please?

word.entryDescription: the number 8
word.entryExample: I go to bed at eight o'clock.

word.entryDescription: the number 18
word.entryExample: My brother is 18 years old.

word.entryDescription: in the position of number eight when we count
word.entryExample: I live on the eighth floor.

word.entryDescription: with a lot of parts or details
word.entryExample: The thieves worked out an elaborate plan to steal the jewels.

word.entryDescription: material that can stretch and return to its usual length or size
word.entryExample: Elastic and string are considered simple accessories.

word.entryDescription: home appliances using electricity
word.entryExample: Recycling electrical goods is difficult because they can't be put in landfill and can't be incinerated.

word.entryDescription: to injure or kill somebody using electricity
word.entryExample: Don't leave a hair-dryer plugged in! It could fall in the bath and electrocute Mike.

word.entryDescription: an electronic device designed to vary an electric motor's speed and its direction
word.entryExample: Could cars equipped with the electronic speed control be the way to stop us committing traffic violations?

word.entryDescription: the quality of being stylish and attractive
word.entryExample: He wore a business suit but still lacked the elegance.

word.entryDescription: graceful and attractive
word.entryExample: The Duchess of Cambridge is an elegant woman who is also a fashion trend-setter.

word.entryDescription: simple or basic; low level
word.entryExample: She speaks French at an elementary level.

word.entryDescription: a very large grey animal with big ears and a thing like a very long nose at the front
word.entryExample: You can see elephants at the zoo.

word.entryDescription: a small room that carries people up and down inside a building
word.entryExample: In America you say 'elevator', in England we say 'lift'.

word.entryDescription: the number 11
word.entryExample: The shops open at eleven on Saturdays.

word.entryDescription: a message you can send by computer
word.entryExample: Sarah sent me an email and invited me to her birthday party.

word.entryDescription: the address of your electronic mail
word.entryExample: What's your email address?

word.entryDescription: feeling uncomfortable because of what other people may think of you
word.entryExample: William was so embarrassed, because I actually snored loudly in the cinema.

word.entryDescription: making you feel ashamed and uncomfortable
word.entryExample: My mum drove to the party and in front of all my friends she said she was disappointed in me. It was so embarrassing.

word.entryDescription: medical care for patients with illnesses or injuries that require immediate attention
word.entryExample: If you need emergency treatment, you should go to Accident and Emergency.

word.entryDescription: calling for urgent action
word.entryExample: This emergent condition in our patient needs our prompt action.

word.entryDescription: someone who likes a type of punk music with emotional and personal lyrics
word.entryExample: My best friend has become an emo and bought a lot of black clothes to reflect his sadness.

word.entryDescription: a strong feeling
word.entryExample: To recognise someone's emotions is to understand how they are feeling.

word.entryDescription: relating to feelings, particularly strong feelings or showing strong feelings
word.entryExample: Being healthy isn't all about diet and exercise – your emotional and mental state affects your body just as much.
